awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nanopillar Electrode Arrays for Highly Sensitive Detection of Neuroelectric Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Nanopillar Electrode Arrays for Highly Sensitive Detection of Neuroelectric Activities

Abstract:  Neurons encode information by electrical signals.  To understand information processing and storage in neuronal networks, one of the most important tactics is to accurately record the small electrical signals generated by individual neurons over time.  However, challenges associated with sensitive and noninvasive detection of small neuroelectric activities have hampered the effort for a better understanding of this complex process.  Intracellular recording is very sensitive in detecting minuscule neuroelectric signals, but it is highly invasive and causes severe damage to the cell membrane.  On the other hand, extracellular recording is non-invasive and very powerful in measuring large numbers of neurons, but it suffers poor signal-to-noise ratio and is unable to detect small synaptic neuroelectric potentials.  This project will develop a novel electrical sensor -- nanopillar electrode arrays -- for highly-sensitive and non-invasive recording of neuroelectric activities.  Nanopillars protruding from the planar surface will enhance the electric coupling between the neuron and the recording electrode.  The new sensor will improve the detection sensitivity by two-orders of magnitude over the current extracellular recording technique.  With the combined advantages of high sensitivity, non-invasiveness, and simultaneous multi-cell recording, the integrated device will enable new studies aimed to understand the mechanisms that govern how neurons in a network coordinate their activities in space and time and how those activities might encode external information.

The proposed research focuses on developing sensitive instrument to facilitate the quantitative measurements of signal propagation in neuronal networks.  The education component of this proposal complements the research goal in (1) incorporating instrumentation fundamentals in an undergraduate laboratory course, (2) introducing research writing and presentation skills to undergraduate lab reports, and (3) mentoring under-privileged high school students in the research laboratory.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to develop new electric sensors based on vertical nanopillars for highly sensitive detection of cellular electric activities. During the period of this award, we have made several seminal contributions to engineering nanoscale electrodes for detecting cell electric activities and understanding the cell-to-electrode interface including (1) engineering Pt vertical nanopillar electrodes for intracellular recording, (2) developing nanoscale probes for nuclear mechanics, and (3) characterizing the nano-bio interface by electron microscopy.

In the nanoelectrode study, we developed nanoscale electrodes that combine the advantages of both intracellular and extracellular methods and demonstrated noninvasive measurement of intracellular action potentials with high sensitivity and high throughput. These nanoscale electrodes take advantage of the cell’s intrinsic tendency to engulf nanosize objects, which promotes adhesion and reduces the current leakage between the cell membrane and the nanoelectrodes. We demonstrated the parallel and non-invasive intracellular recording for over 60 cardiomyocytes and the ability to record intracellularly on the same cell over multiple days. This line of research and its applications were published in Nature Nanotechnology 2012, Nature Communications 2014, Nature Methods 2014, Science 2015, and Microsystems & Nanoengineering 2017.

In the nanomechanics study, we found that nanopillar-induced membrane curvature is communicated through the cytoskeleton to induce nuclear deformation. The mechanical properties of the cell nucleus and its coupling to the cell membrane are crucial to cell migration, cancer metastases and mechanically induced changes in gene expression. The measurements show that nanopillar-induced nuclear deformation is determined by the nuclear stiffness as well as opposing effects from actin and intermediate filaments. As such, vertical nanopillars constitute a novel approach to probe nuclear mechanics in a massively parallel and non-invasive manner. This work, published in Nature Nanotechnology 2015, contributes to our understandings of nuclear mechanosensing and its subsequent regulation on gene transcription.

In the nano-bio interface characterization study, we used transmission electron microscopy to measure the gap distance between the cell membrane and the nanopillars. She found that the membrane-nanopillar junction gap is much tighter than membrane-flat surface gap, which contributes to the increased detection sensitivity by nanopillar electrodes. This work was published in Nano Letters 2012  and ACS nano 2014. We recently developed a new method of using focused-ion-beam milling and scanning electron microscopy for examining the nano-bio interface in situ. At the center of this new method is a new sample preparation procedure that provides high membrane contrasts and preserves biological samples for in situ SEM examination. This work is newly published in ACS Nano 2017.

Through these activities, we contributed significantly to mentorship and human resource development. This program directly supported 6 different graduate students over the course of the award, and four students have successfully completed their Ph.D. degrees. This program also engage students in doing research as early in their academic careers as possible. This program has supported the training of 6 high school students and 8 undergraduate students in the last 5 years, each spending >=2 months of time in the PI’s group in the summer. Several of high school students in the lab were minority students recruited through Stanford RISE (Raising Interest in Science and Engineering) program. Their research experiences had contributed to their admission to top tier universities and have encourages two of them to choose a science major.
